revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} '''Indian Army operations in Jammu and Kashmir''' include security operations such as ''Operation All Out'' and ''Operation Sarp Vinash''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/2018-will-be-less-challenging-operation-all-out-to-continue-jammu-and-kashmir-police-official-1788684|title=2018 Will Be Less Challenging; 'Operation All-Out' To Continue: Jammu And Kashmir Police Official|date=17 December 2017|work=NDTV|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171218151005/https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/2018-will-be-less-challenging-operation-all-out-to-continue-jammu-and-kashmir-police-official-1788684|archive-date=2017-12-18|dead-url=no|df=}}{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/operation-sarp-vinash-army-clears-hill-kaka/articleshow/47305413.cms?from=mdr|title=Operation Sarp Vinash: Army clears Hill Kaka|last=Kumar|first=Devesh|date=2003-05-24|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-07-18}} Other operations include humanitarian missions such as ''Operation Megh Rahat'' and operations with a social aim such as ''Operation Goodwill'' and ''Operation Calm Down''.{{Cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/feacontent.aspx?relid=93711|title=Operation Sadbhavana|last=Ministry of Defence|first=|date=|website=Public Information Bureau, Government of India|access-date=2018-02-19}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/Kashmir-violence-Army-begins-operation-%E2%80%98Calm-Down%E2%80%99/article14636778.ece|title=Kashmir violence: Army begins operation 'Calm Down'|date=2016-09-14|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-02-20|others=PTI, PTI|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} == Security Impact == === Operation All Out === {{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Operation All Out in Jammu & Kashmir{{cite web|url=http://brighterkashmir.com/after-operation-all-out-forces-start-operation-outreach-in-kashmir/|title=After operation 'All Out', Forces start operation 'outreach' in Kashmir|website=brighterkashmir.com}} | image = Kashmir map.svg | image_size = 200px | caption = Map of the Kashmir | date = Ongoing | place = [[Jammu & Kashmir]] | result = | combatant1 = {{flag|India}} * [[File:Flag of the Indian Army.svg|23px]] [[Indian Army]] * [[Garud Commando Force]] * [[Central Reserve Police Force]] * [[Border Security Force]] * [[Jammu and Kashmir Police|J&K Police]] * [[National Security Guard]] | combatant2 = * [[File:Flag_of_Lashkar-e-Taiba.svg|22px]] [[Lashkar-e-Taiba]] * [[File:Jaishi-e-Mohammed.svg|22px]] [[Jaish-e-Mohammed]] * [[Hizbul Mujahideen]] * [[File:Al-badr_flag.png|22px]] [[Al badr]] | strength1 = | strength2 = | casualties1 = 26 killed (2015)
55 killed (2016)http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=181538
78 killed (2017){{cite web |url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/jammu-kashmir/195-security-personnel-killed-in-terror-incidents-in-3-yrs-govt/529919.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118181337/http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/jammu-kashmir/195-security-personnel-killed-in-terror-incidents-in-3-yrs-govt/529919.html |archivedate=2018-01-18 |df= }} 41 killed (2018) | casualties2 = 108 militants killed, 67 arrested (2015)
150 militants killed, 79 arrested (2016)
213 militants killed, 97 arrested (2017)
222 militants killed, 12 arrested (2018)http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=181244http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=181538 }} {{Redirect|Operation All Out|the 2014 Assam operation|Operation All Out (Assam)}} Operation All Out (OAO) a joint offensive launched by Indian security forces in 2017 to flush out militants and terrorists in [[Jammu and Kashmir|Kashmir]] until there is complete peace in the state. Operation All-Out includes the [[Indian Army]], [[Central Reserve Police Force|CRPF]], [[Jammu and Kashmir Police]], [[Border Security Force|BSF]] and [[Intelligence Bureau (India)|IB]]. It was launched against numerous militant groups including [[Lashkar-e-Taiba]], [[Jaish-e-Mohammed]], [[Hizbul Mujahideen]] and [[Al-Badr (Jammu and Kashmir)|Al-Badr]].{{Cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/kashmir-terrorism-all-out-plan-lashkar-hizbul-jaish-militants/1/985335.html|title=Operation All-Out: Army's master plan to flush out terrorists from Kashmir|last=Singh|first=Jitendra Bahadur|date=22 June 2017|work=India Today|access-date=19 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171007173341/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/kashmir-terrorism-all-out-plan-lashkar-hizbul-jaish-militants/1/985335.html|archive-date=2017-10-07|dead-url=no|df=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/206-terrorists-killed-in-jammu-and-kashmir-in-2017-state-police-chief-1794156|title=206 Terrorists Killed In Jammu And Kashmir In 2017: State Police Chief|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2018-04-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312162830/https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/206-terrorists-killed-in-jammu-and-kashmir-in-2017-state-police-chief-1794156|archivedate=2018-03-12|deadurl=no|df=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.firstpost.com/india/kashmir-in-2017-operation-all-out-was-a-success-but-will-force-alone-win-hearts-in-the-valley-4275529.html|title=Kashmir in 2017: Operation All-Out was a success, but will force alone win hearts in the Valley? - Firstpost|website=www.firstpost.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312201604/http://www.firstpost.com/india/kashmir-in-2017-operation-all-out-was-a-success-but-will-force-alone-win-hearts-in-the-valley-4275529.html|archivedate=2018-03-12|deadurl=no|access-date=2018-04-02|df=}} The operation was initiated with the consent of Ministry for Home Affairs Government of India following the unrest in 2016 due to the death of [[Burhan Wani]] and subsequent militant and terrorist attacks in the region such as the Amarnath Yatra terror attack on 10 July 2017 in which eight Hindu pilgrims were killed and at least 18 others injured.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailyo.in/politics/kashmir-militancy-hizbul-mujahideen-indian-army/story/1/20687.html|title=Indian Army's 'Operation All Out' in Kashmir killed 190 terrorists, but there is reason to worry|last=Sandhu|first=Kamaljit|date=20 November 2017|work=Daily News and Analysis India (DNA)|access-date=19 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222105042/https://www.dailyo.in/politics/kashmir-militancy-hizbul-mujahideen-indian-army/story/1/20687.html|archive-date=2017-12-22|dead-url=no|df=}} === Operation Calm Down === Operation Calm Down was started by the [[Indian Army|Indian army]] in [[Jammu and Kashmir]] following the aftermath of the death of [[Burhan Wani]] in July 2016 which had led to [[2016 Kashmir Unrest|unrest in Kashmir]] in which more than 90 civilians and 2 security personnel were killed and thousands injured.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/Kashmir-violence-Army-begins-operation-%E2%80%98Calm-Down%E2%80%99/article14636778.ece|title=Kashmir violence: Army begins operation ‘Calm Down’|date=2016-09-14|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-02-20|others=PTI, PTI|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-3787847/Indian-Army-launches-Operation-Calm-troubled-Kashmir-soldiers-told-maintain-maximum-restraint-face-violent-protests.html|title=Indian Army launches 'Operation Calm Down' in troubled Kashmir Valley|last=|first=|date=|work=Daily Mail Online|access-date=2018-02-20|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} It was started in September 2016. Over 4000 additional troops were deployed as part of Operation Calm Down to bring back order to the region, but direct instructions were given to the troops to use minimal force. The troops were mainly deployed in South Kashmir.{{Cite news|url=https://scroll.in/latest/816469/indian-army-deploys-operation-calm-down-to-south-kashmir-to-tackle-protestors-and-militants|title=Indian Army deploys operation 'calm down' to South Kashmir to tackle protestors and militants|last=Staff|first=Scroll|work=Scroll.in|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thequint.com/news/india/operation-calm-down-kashmiris-get-jadoo-ki-jhappi-from-the-army-munnaibhai-mbbs|title=Operation Calm Down: Kashmiris Get ‘Jadoo Ki Jhappi’ From the Army|work=The Quint|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en}} Schools, shops and connectivity to some regions in Kashmir had been lost for over three months due to the unrest and militancy and Operation Calm Down aimed to undo this.{{Cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/kashmir-army-uses-operations-calm-down-and-jadoo-ki-jhappi-for-law-and-order-in-anantnag-3024400.html|title=Kashmir: Army uses operations 'Calm Down' and 'Jadoo ki Jhappi' for law and order in Anantnag - Firstpost|website=www.firstpost.com|access-date=2018-02-20}} === Operation Sarp Vinash === Operation Sarp Vinash (Snake Destroyer) is an operation undertaken by Indian army to flush out terrorists who made bases in the Hilkaka [[Poonch district, India|Poonch]]-[[Surankote Tehsil|Surankot]] area of the [[Pir Panjal Range|Pir Panjal]] range in [[Jammu and Kashmir]] during April–May 2003.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/operation-sarp-vinash-army-clears-hill-kaka/articleshow/47305413.cms?from=mdr|title=Operation Sarp Vinash: Army clears Hill Kaka|last=Kumar|first=Devesh|date=2003-05-24|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-03-07}} In the operation the [[Indian army]] killed 64 terrorists belonging to various [[Jihadist terrorism|jihadist]] outfits.{{cite web|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/website/story/reassessing-operation-sarp-vinash/220439 |title=Reassessing Operation Sarp Vinash |publisher=Outlookindia.com |date= |accessdate=2016-11-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2003/may/23josy1.htm |title=Operation 'Sarp Vinash': Over 60 terrorists killed |publisher=Rediff.com |date=2003-05-24 |accessdate=2016-11-20}} The system of hideouts used by the terrorists found during this operation was the largest ever in the known history of [[insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=hYQsDBIgEkYC&pg=PA342&dq=Operation+Sarp+Vinash&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi607y9jtvZAhUKOY8KHYNLDOwQ6AEIPzAE#v=onepage&q=Operation%20Sarp%20Vinash&f=false|title=Terrorism in Northern India: Jammu and Kashmir and the Punjab|last=Prakash|first=Ved|publisher=Gyan Publishing House|isbn=9788178357034|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2003/07/31/stories/2003073102911200.htm|title=The Hindu : Fernandes reveals 'Sarp Vinash' toll|website=www.thehindu.com|access-date=2018-03-07}} '''Background''' Over several years, terrorists of groups like [[Lashkar-e-Taiba]] (LeT), [[Harkat-ul-Jihad al-Islami|Harkat-ul-Jihad-e-Islami]], [[Al-Badr (Jammu and Kashmir)|al-Badr]] and [[Jaish-e-Mohammed|Jaish-e-Mohammad]] (JeM) had been building up safe houses and safe areas in strategic areas of the region of [[Pir Panjal Range|Pir Panjal]] in [[Poonch district, India|Poonch]] for many years over a region of 150 sq kilometers.{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Army-defends-operation-Sarp-Vinash/articleshow/66259.cms|title=Army defends operation Sarp Vinash - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-03-07}} The network of bunkers and shelters around the region known as Hill Kaka in Surankote numbered nearly over a hundred, and were intermingled with shelters used by local herdsmen. 9 Para-Commando Regiment were called to capture Peak 3689 in Hill Kaka after surveillance picked up footprints converging at one location. 13 terrorists were killed in this, the single largest number during operation Sarp Vinash. 6 [[Rashtriya Rifles]], 163 Brigade, 100 Brigade and the 15 Corps were also called in for operations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.outlookindia.com/website/story/operation-sarp-vinash/220331|title=Operation Sarp Vinash|last=|first=|date=|work=Outlook India|access-date=2018-03-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} From diaries captured from killed terrorists, the presence of a rudimentary counter-intelligence system of the terrorist organisations was revealed, which involved killing women and children who had given up information to Indian security forces. An extensive communications system using portable satellite phones was also found which allowed the terrorists to contact handlers in Pakistan and India.{{Cite web|url=http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/sair/Archives/1_46.htm|title=A Militia Against Terror {{!}} J&K: Operation Sarp Vinash - The Army Strikes Hard {{!}} South Asia Intelligence Review (SAIR), Vol. No. 1.46|website=www.satp.org|access-date=2018-03-07}} '''Aftermath''' Paratrooper [[Sanjog Chhetri]], 9 [[Para (Special Forces)|Para (SF)]], was awarded an [[Ashoka Chakra (military decoration)|Ashoka Chakra]] in 2004 posthumously for his role in the Operation Sarp Vinash in which he succumbed.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=8LjjDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT123&dq=indian+army+para+special+forces+selection&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiyk9nl-NrZAhXGP48KHXrJDkoQ6AEISTAH#v=onepage&q=indian%20army%20para%20special%20forces%20selection&f=false|title=Ashoka Chakra Recipients|last=Aggarwal|first=Rashmi|date=101|publisher=Prabhat Prakashan|language=en}} During Operation Sarp Vinash, media claims of different Indian media houses about what actually happened during the operation were hyped and very contradictory.{{Cite news|url=https://www.outlookindia.com/website/story/reassessing-operation-sarp-vinash/220439|title=Reassessing Operation Sarp Vinash|last=|first=|date=|work=Outlook India|access-date=2018-03-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} == Operation Sadbhavana (Goodwill) == '''Operation Sadbhavana''', also referred to as '''Operation Goodwill''' has been launched in [[Jammu and Kashmir]] by the [[Indian Army]] under their Military Civic Action programmes, which are aimed at "[[Winning hearts and minds|Winning the Hearts and Minds]]" (WHAM) of the people in the region. ''Sadbhavna'' literally means 'harmony', therefore the operation can also be interpreted as Operation Harmony. The catchphrase of the operation is "''Jawan aur Awam, Aman Hai Muqaam''” (peace is the destination for both the people and the soldier).Dr. Arpita Anant. (2011) ''Counterinsurgency and “Op Sadhbhavana” in Jammu and Kashmir.'' [[Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses]] New Delhi. https://idsa.in/system/files/OP_CounterinsurgencyKashmir.pdf{{Cite journal|last=Cariappa|first=Mudera|date=1 August 2008|title=Operation Sadbhavana: Winning Hearts and Minds in the Ladakh Himalayan Region|url=https://academic.oup.com/milmed/article/173/8/749/4371542|journal=Military Medicine|volume= 173, August 2008|pages=749–753|via=Oxford Academic}}Rahul K Bhonsle (2009). Manekshaw Paper No. 14, 2009 ''Winning Hearts and Minds Lessons from Jammu and Kashmir''. [[Centre for Land Warfare Studies]] Welfare initiatives under Operation Sadbhavana include infrastructure development, medical care, women and youth empowerment, educational tours and sports tournaments among other initiatives. Over 450 crore rupees (70 million US$) has been directly spent on this programme and more funding provided through donors. The projects are planned according to the needs and desires of the local population and are handed over to the state government after successful initiation. 'Operation Sadbhavana' is a resolve by the Indian army to come closer to the population in Jammu and Kashmir and develop mutual faith and trust which the army gets across the rest of India.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/The-violence-of-compassion/article11542295.ece|title=The violence of compassion|last=Qanungo|first=Nawaz Gul|date=2014-02-18|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-02-19|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/jammu-kashmir/community/how-successful-has-sadbhavana-been-in-kashmir/233100.html|title=How successful has Sadbhavana been in Kashmir|last=|first=|date=|work=Tribune India|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} === Background === Operation Sadbhavana was officially launched in 1998, especially in rural areas near the [[Line of Control]] (LOC) where [[Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir|insurgency]] and militancy had caused destruction to property and a sense of alienation among the people of Jammu and Kashmir from the rest of India. === Initiatives === '''Army Super-30 Initiative''' In 2013, the Indian Army teamed up with the New Delhi-based NGO, Centre for Social Responsibility and Leadership (CSRL), to launch the Super-30 initiative along the lines of the highly acclaimed and successful [[Super 30|Super-30]] concept started by [[Abhayanand]] in [[Bihar]]. Over time the initiative included more students and was subsequently called the Army Super-40, and soon will become the Army Super-50. Nine students of the 2016-17 Army Super-40 batch cleared the difficult [[IIT JEE|IIT-JEE]] advanced examination. Various Indian organizations have provided funding for this project including Power Grid India contributing for the first batch, the Rural Electrification Council (REC) contributing for the second batch and the [[Tata Group|TATA]] Relief Committee funding the third batch.{{Cite news|url=http://www.defenceinfo.com/army-super-40-initiative-provides-road-map-youth-development|title=Army Super-40 initiative provides road map for youth development|date=2017-06-17|work=Defence Info India {{!}} Defence News & Views of India, Analysis of Indian Defence|access-date=2018-02-19|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.defenceinfo.com/indian-armys-super-30-in-kashmir-attains-excellent-results|title=Indian Army’s Super 30 in Kashmir attains excellent results|date=2016-05-06|work=Defence Info India {{!}} Defence News & Views of India, Analysis of Indian Defence|access-date=2018-02-19|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.defenceinfo.com/government-must-take-a-leaf-from-army-super-40-education-initiative|title=Government must take a leaf from Army Super – 40 education initiative|last=|first=|date=2016-12-25|work=Defence Info India - Defence News & Views of India, Analysis of Indian Defence|access-date=2018-02-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} '''Schools''' The Indian Army has established 53 English medium Army Goodwill Schools in places in Jammu and Kashmir such as [[Rajouri]], [[Poonch]], [[Boniyar]], [[Uri, Jammu and Kashmir|Uri]] ([[Baramulla]]), [[Khanabal]] ([[Anantnag]]), Karu ([[Leh]]), [[Kargil]] and Chandigam ([[Kupwara]]). Assistance has also been provided to approximately 2700 public schools. These army schools are known to provide undisturbed and good quality education even during times of unrest.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thequint.com/videos/news-videos/army-gives-free-education-in-kashmir|title=Operation Sadbhavna: Army’s Bid to Provide Free Education in J&K|work=The Quint|access-date=2018-02-19|language=en}} Army Goodwill Schools operating under the shelter of Operation Sadbhavana are educating more than 10000 students in the [[Kashmir Valley]] itself and over 14000 students in Jammu and Kashmir.{{Cite news|url=http://www.defenceinfo.com/heed-army-chiefs-call-challenge-radicalisation-jk|title=Heed Army Chief’s call to challenge radicalisation in J&K|date=2018-01-17|work=Defence Info India {{!}} Defence News & Views of India, Analysis of Indian Defence|access-date=2018-02-19|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/should-indian-army-take-over-running-schools-training-centres-for-an-incompetent-state-govt-3044090.html|title=Should Indian Army take over running schools, training centres for an incompetent state govt? - Firstpost|website=www.firstpost.com|access-date=2018-02-19}} '''Women Empowerment Centres''' Here women are taught various skills, awareness is raised about health and birth control, information regarding banking and loan procedures is imparted, basic education is imparted including operating computers, fashion designing and craft related skills. Under this initiative centers such as the Women’s Vocational Training Centre, Poonch, Usha Fashion Design School, Baramulla and Women Empowerment Centre, Baramulla have been set up.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyexcelsior.com/army-launches-tailoring-course-for-women/|title=Army launches tailoring course for women|last=|first=|date=|work=Daily Excelsior|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} '''Model Villages''' Model Villages set up under Operation Sadbhavana include Chandigam Model Village, Lolab (Kupwara) and Sagra Model Village, Mendhar (Poonch). '''Educational/Motivational Tours''' Between 2012 and 2015, the Indian army conducted over 250 educational, national integration and capacity building tours (CBTs) and in each tour around 30 members A Military Hospital in Kargil has also been set up which also caters to civilians with various services being free of cost. The Pritam Spiritual Foundation (Poonch) under Operation Sadbhavana has provided [[Artificial Limbs|artificial limbs]] free of cost to over 3100 people who have been victims of militancy, mine blasts or crossborder firing. Under operation Sadbhavana veterinary aid camps and free treatment to civil animals are also offered.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Delhi/remount-veterinary-corps-celebrates-237th-raising-day/article7988853.ece|title=Remount Veterinary Corps celebrates 237th Raising Day|date=2015-12-15|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-02-19|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} '''Sports''' The Indian army organises various sporting events in Jammu and Kashmir in coordination with local sports bodies. Some events that has been conducted under this initiative includes the Baramulla Girls Badminton League, Baramulla Cricket Premier League, Kupwara Premier Football League, Gingle Volleyball League. As many thirty two teams participated in the cricket tournament even as sixteen teams participated in the football tournament.{{Cite news|url=http://www.defenceinfo.com/army-encourages-aspirations-of-new-age-kashmiri-youth|title=Army encourages aspirations of new age Kashmiri youth|date=2015-10-22|work=Defence Info India {{!}} Defence News & Views of India, Analysis of Indian Defence|access-date=2018-02-19|language=en-US}} == Timeline == === Summary === {| class="wikitable" |+A tabular view of the number of militants killed !Year !2017 !2018 |- |January |12 |13 |- |February |10 |6 |- |March |9 |23 |- |April |8 |19 |- |May |16 | 18 |- |June |21 | 26 |- |July |27 |11 |- |August |25 | 25 |- |September |16 |31 |- |October |17 | 26 |- |November |19 | 37 |- |December |12 | - |} === 2017 === A total of 213 militants were killed under the operation by the Indian security forces in 2017. page.title: International Convention concerning the Use of Broadcasting in the Cause of Peace

revision.comment: /* Signatories and state parties */clean up using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''International Convention concerning the Use of Broadcasting in the Cause of Peace''' is a 1936 [[League of Nations]] [[multilateral treaty|treaty]] whereby states agreed to prohibit the use of [[broadcasting]] for [[propaganda]] or the spreading of false news. It was the first international treaty to bind states to "restrict expression which constituted a threat to international peace and security".<ref name = kearney>Michael G. Kearney, ''The Prohibition of Propaganda for War in International Law'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2007 {{ISBN|9780199232451}}) pp. 28–33.</ref>
==Creation== In 1933, the Assembly of the League of Nations authorised the drafting of a multilateral treaty on propaganda. The Convention resulted and it was concluded and signed on 23 September 1936 at a conference in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. The Convention entered into force on 2 April 1938.
==Content== Article 1 of the Convention obligates the state parties to prohibit and stop any broadcast transmission within their territories that are "of such a character as to incite the population of any territory to acts incompatible with the internal order or the security of a territory"; this article was intended to prohibit and stop propaganda from being broadcast that would incite listeners to revolution.<ref name = kearney/>
Article 2 of the Convention contains a similar mandate by prohibiting broadcasts that would constitute "incitement to war against another high contracting party". The Article makes no distinction between the speech of the state and the speech of private individuals.<ref name = kearney/>
Articles 3 and 4 prohibits the broadcasting of false news, and Article 5 states that parties to the agreement will, upon request, provide information to foreign broadcasting services that can be used to promote knowledge and understanding of the "civilization and conditions of life of his own country".
==History of legacy== Upon the outbreak of the [[Second World War]], there were 22 parties to the Convention. The effect of the Convention was severely limited by the fact that [[Nazi Germany|Germany]], [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]], and [[Empire of Japan|Japan]]‒states which waged extensive propaganda campaigns throughout the 1930s and World War II–were not parties to the Convention. Significantly, [[Republic of China (1912–49)|China]], the [[United States]], and the [[Soviet Union]] also chose to not ratify the Convention,<ref>Although the Soviet Union did ratify in 1983.</ref> the U.S. on [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] grounds.
After the Second World War, depositary functions for the Convention passed from the League of Nations to the [[United Nations]]. In 1954, the [[United Nations General Assembly]] recognised that the Convention "was an important element in the field of freedom of information".<ref>[https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/841(IX)&Lang=E&Area=RESOLUTION Resolution 841 (IX)], 17 December 1954.</ref> The General Assembly authorised the drafting of a Protocol which would supplement and update the Convention; however, when the draft Protocol attracted little support, the UN "abandoned all efforts at reviving the Convention".<ref name = kearney/>
Beginning in the 1960s, the Convention continued to be ratified by a few states, particularly those in the [[Communist bloc]]. However, during the 1980s, it was [[denunciation|denounced]] by [[Australia]], [[France]], the [[Netherlands]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. It was most recently ratified by [[Liberia]] in 2005. As of 2013, it is in force for 29 states.
==Signatories and state parties== The following states became parties to the Convention by ratifying, acceding to, or declaring succession to it. Parties that signed the Convention on 23 September 1936 are indicated in bold. Parties that have subsequently denounced the Convention are indicated and the date of ratification is in italics. {| class="wikitable sortable" !State !Ratification !Notes |- |{{flagicon|Afghanistan|1980}} [[Democratic Republic of Afghanistan|Afghanistan]] |8 Feb 1985 | |- |{{flag|Australia}} |''25 Jun 1937'' |At the time of ratification, extended the treaty to the [[Territory of New Guinea]], the [[Territory of Papua]], the [[Nauru Trust Territory]], and [[Norfolk Island]]. [[Denunciation|Denounced]] the treaty for itself and the dependencies still under its control on 17 May 1985. |- |'''{{flagicon|Brazil|1889}} [[Vargas Era|Brazil]]''' |11 Feb 1938 | |- |{{flagicon|Bulgaria|1971}} [[People's Republic of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]] |17 May 1972 | |- |{{flagicon|Cameroon|1961}} [[Cameroon]] |19 Jun 1967 |Declared succession from extension to [[French Cameroons]]. |- |'''{{flag|Chile}}''' |20 Feb 1940 | |- |'''{{flag|Czechoslovakia}}''' |18 Sep 1984 |Ratification currently in force for no state. |- |'''{{flag|Denmark}}''' |11 Oct 1937 |Extends to [[Faroe Islands]] and [[Greenland]]. |- |'''{{flagicon|Egypt|1922}} [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]]''' |29 Jul 1938 | |- |{{flag|El Salvador}} |18 Aug 1938 |Ratified as "Salvador". |- |'''{{flag|Estonia}}''' |18 Aug 1938 | |- |{{flag|Finland}} |29 Nov 1938 | |- |'''{{flagicon|France}} [[French Third Republic|France]]''' |''8 Mar 1938'' |On 14 Jan 1939, extended the treaty to all exclusively French colonies and protectorates and to territories under French [[League of Nations Mandate|mandate]]: [[French Algeria|Algeria]], [[French Cameroons]], [[Clipperton Island]], [[French Madagascar|Madagascar]] (including [[French Comoros|Comoros]]), [[French Equatorial Africa]], [[Guadeloupe]], [[French Guiana]], [[French India]], [[French Indochina]], [[Martinique]], [[French Morocco|Morocco]], [[New Caledonia]] (including [[Wallis and Futuna]]), [[French Polynesia]], [[Réunion]], [[Saint Pierre and Miquelon]], [[French Somaliland]], [[French Mandate for Syria and the Lebanon|Mandate for Syria and the Lebanon]], [[French Togoland]], [[French Protectorate of Tunisia|Tunisia]], and [[French West Africa]] . On 14 Jul 1939, extended the treaty to the Anglo-French [[Condominium (international law)|condominium]] of [[New Hebrides]]. Denounced the treaty for itself and the dependencies still under its control on 13 Apr 1984. |- |{{flag|East Germany}} |30 Aug 1984 |Ratification is currently in force for no state. |- |{{flag|Guatemala}} |18 Nov 1938 | |- |{{flag|Holy See}} |5 Jan 1967 | |- |{{flagicon|Hungary|1957}} [[People's Republic of Hungary|Hungary]] |20 Sep 1984 | |- |'''{{flag|British India}}''' |11 Aug 1937 |Ratification is currently in force for the [[India|Republic of India]]. |- |{{flag|Irish Free State}} |25 May 1938 | |- |{{flagicon|Laos|1952}} [[Kingdom of Laos|Laos]] |23 Mar 1966 | |- |{{flag|Latvia}} |25 Apr 1939 | |- |{{flag|Liberia}} |16 Sep 2005 | |- |'''{{flag|Luxembourg}}''' |8 Feb 1938 | |- |{{flag|Malta}} |1 Apr 1966 |Declared succession from extension to [[Malta Colony]]. |- |{{flagicon|Mauritius}} [[Mauritius (1968–1992)|Mauritius]] |18 Jul 1969 |Declared succession from extension to [[British Mauritius]]. |- |{{flagicon|Mongolia}} [[Mongolian People's Republic|Mongolia]] |10 Jul 1985 | |- |'''{{flag|Netherlands}}''' |''15 Feb 1939'' |At the time of ratification, extended the treaty to the [[Dutch East Indies]], [[Surinam (Dutch colony)|Surinam]], and [[Curaçao and Dependencies]]. [[Denunciation|Denounced]] the treaty for itself and the dependencies still under its control on 10 Oct 1982. |- |'''{{flag|New Zealand}}''' |27 Jan 1938 | |- |'''{{flag|Norway}}''' |5 May 1938 | |- |{{flagicon|South Africa|1928}} [[South Africa]] |30 Dec 1938 | |- |'''{{flag|Soviet Union}}''' |3 Feb 1983 |Ratification currently applies to the [[Russian Federation]]. |- |{{flag|Sweden}} |22 June 1938 | |- |'''{{flag|Switzerland}}''' |8 Feb 1938 | |- |'''{{flag|United Kingdom}}''' |''18 Aug 1937'' |On 13 Oct 1937, extended the treaty to [[British Burma|Burma]]. On 1 Nov 1937, extended it to [[Southern Rhodesia]]. On 14 Jul 1939, extended it to [[Colony of Aden]], [[Colony of the Bahamas|Bahamas]], [[Colony of Barbados|Barbados]], [[Basutoland]], [[Bechuanaland Protectorate|Bechuanaland]], [[Bermuda]], [[British Guiana]], [[British Honduras]], [[British Ceylon|Ceylon]], [[British Cyprus (1878–1960)|Cyprus]], [[Falkland Islands]] [[Falkland Islands Dependencies|and Dependencies]], [[Colonial Fiji|Fiji]], [[British Gambia|Gambia]], [[Gibraltar]], [[Gilbert and Ellice Islands]], [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] (including [[British Togoland]]), [[British Hong Kong|Hong Kong]], [[Colony of Jamaica|Jamaica]] (including [[Turks and Caicos Islands]] and [[Cayman Islands]]), [[Kenya Colony|Kenya]], [[British Leeward Islands|Leeward Islands]], [[Federated Malay States]], [[Unfederated Malay States]], [[History of Brunei|Brunei]], [[Malta Colony|Malta]], [[British Mauritius|Mauritius]], [[New Hebrides]], [[Colony and Protectorate of Nigeria]], [[British Cameroons]], [[Crown Colony of North Borneo|North Borneo]], [[Northern Rhodesia]], [[Nyasaland]], [[Mandatory Palestine]], [[Saint Helena and Dependencies|Saint Helena and Ascension]], [[Crown Colony of Sarawak|Sarawak]], [[Crown Colony of Seychelles|Seychelles]], [[Colony of Sierra Leone|Sierra Leone]], [[British Somaliland]], [[Straits Settlements]], [[History of Swaziland|Swaziland]], [[Tanganyika Territory|Tanganyika]], [[History of Tonga|Tonga]], [[Emirate of Transjordan|Transjordan]], [[Crown Colony of Trinidad and Tobago|Trinidad and Tobago]], [[Uganda Protectorate|Uganda]], [[British Windward Islands|Windward Islands]], and [[Sultanate of Zanzibar|Zanzibar]]. [[Denunciation|Denounced]] the treaty for itself and the dependencies still under its control on 24 Jul 1985. |- |{{flag|Zimbabwe}} |1 Dec 1998 |Declared succession from extension to [[Southern Rhodesia]]. |}
The other states that signed the Convention but have not ratified it are [[Kingdom of Albania (1928–39)|Albania]], [[Argentina]], [[First Austrian Republic|Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Colombia]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Kingdom of Greece|Greece]], [[Lithuania]], [[Mexico]], [[Kingdom of Romania|Romania]], [[Second Spanish Republic|Spain]], [[Turkey]], and [[Uruguay]].

{{Infobox political party |name = Left of Croatia |native_name = Ljevica Hrvatske |logo = |colorcode = red |founder = |leader1_title = President |leader1_name = Ivan Ninić |leader2_title = |leader2_name = |founded = {{Start date|2001|11|16|df=y}} |headquarters = [[Rijeka]] |ideology = [[Democratic socialism]] (constitutional position)
[[Anti-fascism]]
[[Left-wing populism]] |position = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] |colors = Red |symbol = |country = Croatia |footnotes = }} The '''Left of Croatia''' ({{lang-hr|Ljevica Hrvatske}}) is a marginal [[leftist]] [[Croatia]]n [[political party]] with no parliamentary representation.[http://www.hidra.hr/stranke/s028469h.htm STR: Iskaznica] ==Origins== Left of Croatia was created in 2007 by the merger of several parties: * Vladimir Bebić – Third Block * Green Left of Croatia * Social Democratic Union * Dalmatian Assembly * Olive * Socialist Party of Croatia – Left Alternative * [[Ivan Ninić]], an [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia|SDP]] [[dissident]] The '''Social Democratic Union''' ({{lang-hr|Socijalnodemokratska unija}}) was founded in 1992, following Croatian independence, being one of very few political parties to identify itself as left-wing. Most of their members were former Communists or left-wingers displeased embracing Croatian nationalism, the excesses of privatisation and human rights abuses of ethnic minorities. The first leader of the party was [[Branko Horvat]], noted economist and one of the few Croatian intellectuals to oppose dissolution of [[SFR Yugoslavia]]. In the early 1990s SDU was one of the few political parties to openly advocate co-operation and integration of Croatia with other republics of former Yugoslavia a view very different from the current Croatian political mainstream. On [[Croatian parliamentary election, 1992|1992 parliamentary elections]] it turned out that SDU nevertheless enjoyed some degree of support, especially among [[Serbs of Croatia|ethnic Serbs]] living in government-controlled territories. Although it failed to break the 2% vote threshold of entry into the [[Croatian Parliament]], SDU could have hoped to win three seats by fulfilling the constitutional quota of ethnic Serbs in Sabor. Instead, the [[Croatian Constitutional Court]], in one of the most controversial decisions in their history, ruled that the seats should go to [[Serb People's Party (Croatia)|Serb People's Party]] as an "ethnic party", and presumably the only true representative of ethnic Serb minority, despite the fact SNS won fewer votes than SDU. SDU had some success in the local elections held a few months later, but the biggest boost came to them with parliamentary status gained when [[Vladimir Bebić]], a colourful member of Sabor from [[Rijeka]], decided to join their ranks. Bebić, who enjoyed a great deal of popularity in the Croatian public, gradually became the party's leader. In the 1995 election he managed to increase SDU's vote margin, but with increased vote threshold (5%), SDU failed to enter Sabor. This, the appearance of more mainstream left-wing parties, and the establishment of a rejuvenated SDP as Croatia's main opposition party, led to SDU becoming more marginalised, struck with internal divisions and gradually phased out in late 1990s. After the [[Socialist Labour Party of Croatia]] (SRP) was formed, many SDU members joined that organization. SDU formed joint lists for local elections in 2005 with the SRP, the Green Party and the Green Left of Croatia, but failed to enter any of the regional assemblies. The '''Socialist Party of Croatia – Left Alternative''' ({{lang-hr|Socijalistička partija Hrvatske - lijeva alternativa}}) was a leftist party formed in 2004 when several members left the [[Socialist Labour Party of Croatia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/u-zagrebu-osnovana-nova-politicka-stranka-socijalisticka-partija-hrvatske--lijeva-alternativa/213540.aspx|title=U Zagrebu osnovana nova politička stranka: Socijalistička partija Hrvatske - Lijeva alternativa|work=[[Index.hr]]|date=17 July 2004|language=Croatian|accessdate=11 May 2013}} In the local elections in 2005, the party had a joint lists with the [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia]] in the town of [[Glina, Croatia|Glina]] and with the [[Independent Democratic Serb Party]] in [[Sisak-Moslavina County]], where it gained one seat in the assembly.{{cite web|url=http://www.izbori.hr/arhiva/arhiva2005Lokalni/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-06-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070531200706/http://www.izbori.hr/arhiva/arhiva2005Lokalni/index.html |archivedate=2007-05-31 |df= }} The '''Green Left of Croatia''' ({{lang-hr|Zelena ljevica Hrvatske}}) was a leftist party formed in 2001 whose political platform was [[Ecological Socialism|ecological socialism]]. On the local elections in 2005, it formed a joint list with [[Social Democratic Union (Croatia)|Social Democratic Union]] and two other [[green parties]]. Coalition got 0.39% vote in Zagreb. It ceased to exist in 2006 and in 2007 merged into the Left of Croatia. ==Ideology== The Party sees itself as the protector of the workers and other [[disadvantaged]] parts of society. It considers the [[Croatian privatization controversy|privatization process in the nineties]] to be criminal and supports free education and healthcare. [[Antifascism]] is declared to be one of basis of the party and it attended [[Josip Broz Tito]]'s birthday celebration. The party claims to support [[small business]] in competition with “foreign capital”. It also supports [[Accession of Croatia to the European Union|EU]] and [[gay rights]], and opposes [[NATO]] membership. The Left aims to present itself as a strongly [[Political corruption|anti-corruption]] party.[http://www.ljevica.hr/politika.html Ljevica Hrvatske] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928041841/http://www.ljevica.hr/politika.html |date=2007-09-28 }} ==Leadership== The Party is led by Croatian politician and former [[Sportsperson|athlete]] [[Ivan Ninić]], a former [[Member of Parliament]]. Before his death in 2009, a prominent leader was [[Vladimir Bebić]], another former MP. ==Local representation== Ljevica was represented in the council of [[Rijeka]] by two councillors and by three in assembly of [[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]]. All were elected from the electoral list "Vladimir Bebić – Third Block list on the [[Croatian local elections, 2005]]. ==2007 elections== Soon after its founding [[congress]], the Party announced that it will have a joint list with [[Istrian Socialdemocratic Forum]] and [[Croatian Socialdemocrats]] in [[Istria]] and [[Rijeka]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nacional.hr/articles/view/34338/ |title=Stvorena koalicija ISDF-a i Ljevice Hrvatske |trans-title=An ISDF and Croatian Left coalition is formed |language=Croatian |work=[[Nacional (weekly)|Nacional]] |author=Martina Zeković |date=14 May 2007 |accessdate=30 June 2012 |archivedate=30 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68ohQ7eLr?url=http://www.nacional.hr/clanak/34338/stvorena-koalicija-isdf-a-i-ljevice-hrvatske |deadurl=no |df= }} The Left also announced a coalition with [[Socialist Labour Party of Croatia]] one month before the elections.{{cite web |url=http://izbori.hrt.hr/content/view/548/29/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117063123/http://izbori.hrt.hr/content/view/548/29/ |archivedate=2008-01-17 |df= }} ==2009 local elections== For the 2009 local elections in Rijeka, Ljevica joined with [[Independent Democratic Serb Party]] and with [[Women's Democratic Party]] for Zagreb local elections. == See also == *''[[Hrvatska ljevica]]'' *''[[Novi Plamen]]'' * [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia]] * [[Socialist Labour Party of Croatia ]] * [[Socialist Party of Croatia]] * [[Social Democratic Union (Croatia)]] * [[Social Democratic Action of Croatia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Croatian political parties}} [[Category:2001 establishments in Croatia]] [[Category:Anti-fascism in Croatia]] [[Category:Anti-fascist organizations]] [[Category:Democratic socialist parties in Europe]] [[Category:Left-wing populist parties]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2001]] [[Category:Socialist parties in Croatia]]

'''Let Veneto Decide''' ({{lang-it|Il Veneto Decida}}) was a cross-party committee campaigning for a referendum on the independence of [[Veneto]] from [[Italy]].
The committee was first launched in [[Venice]] on 25 July 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rovigooggi.it/articolo/2013-07-26/una-fondazione-per-consultare-i-veneti-sull-autodeterminazione/#.Uh8RG395epM |title=Una Fondazione per consultare i Veneti sull'autodeterminazione - INDIPENDENZA DEL VENETO Presentata l’iniziativa "Il Veneto decida" a sostegno del progetto di legge referendaria 342 appoggiata da tutti gli indipendentisti|publisher=Rovigooggi.it |date= |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.veneto-stato.eu/il-veneto-decida/ |title=Il Veneto decida | Veneto StatoVeneto Stato |publisher=Veneto-stato.eu |date=2014-01-22 |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref> and was officially presented during a convention in [[Vedelago]] on 4 September.<ref>http://www.lindipendenza.com/il-problema-del-veneto-e-litalia-avanti-tutta-verso-lindipendenza/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indipendenzaveneta.com/news/2013/09/05/pressing-sul-consiglio-regionale/ |title=Pressing sul Consiglio Regionale Indipendenza Veneta |publisher=Indipendenzaveneta.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref> The committee comprises or is supported by several [[Venetian nationalism|Venetist]] parties, associations and individuals, notably including: *[[Venetian Independence]] *[[Veneto State]] *[[Liga Veneta Repubblica]] *[[Veneto First]] *[[Popular Future]] *[[Independentist Youth]] *Raixe Venete *16° Reggimento Treviso *Pasque Veronesi *Right to Vote *[[Lombard Committee for Resolution 44]]
In March 2014 the committee was almost completely supplanted by the birth of United for Independent Veneto, composed of [[Independent Venetians]] (a split of Venetian Independence), Veneto State, Liga Veneta Repubblica and Popular Future.<ref>http://www.consiglioveneto.it/crvportal/pageContainer.jsp?p=84&n=81&c=5&e=91&t=0&idEvento=6492</ref> The coalition was later transformed into [[Independence We Veneto]].

The number of seats has increased over time, from eight for the first election in 1900, to the current nineteen. Since 1978, each [[Electoral district (Canada)|riding]] (electoral district) has elected one member by [[first past the post]] to the [[Yukon Legislative Assembly]]. [[Political party|Political parties]] were officially recognized and registered beginning in 1978.{{cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Infoparl/english/issue.htm?param=68&art=113 |title=Yukon Celebrates its 100th Anniversary |work=Canadian Parliamentary Review |accessdate=2006-12-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050214112538/http://www.parl.gc.ca/infoparl/english/issue.htm?param=68&art=113 |archivedate=February 14, 2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The chart on the right shows the information graphically, with the most recent elections on the right (going as far back as the introduction of political parties in 1978). The [[Yukon Party]] (which was named the Yukon Progressive Conservative Party prior to 1992) has been the most successful since political parties were officially recognised, having won six out of ten elections. The [[Yukon New Democratic Party|NDP]] have won three elections, and the [[Yukon Liberal Party|Liberal]] party have won two elections. ==1978–present== === Summary of results=== The table below shows the total number of seats won by the major political parties at each election. It also shows the percentage of the vote obtained by the major political parties at each election. The winning party's total's are shown in bold. There has been only one election (in 1985) where the party that formed the government did not have the largest share of the vote. From the territory's creation in 1898 until 1978, the Yukon was governed by a federally appointed [[Commissioner#Canadian territories|Commissioner]] advised by the Territorial Council. The Territorial council was wholly appointed from 1898 to 1900; part elected, part appointed from 1900 to 1908; and wholly elected from 1909 to 1978. The number of members varied considerably during the council's 80-year history. The 1900 election elected just two out of eight members; the elections from 1903 to 1907 elected five out of ten members. The wholly elected Council comprised ten members from 1909, which was reduced to three starting with the 1920 election. The number of members was increased to five as of the 1952 election, seven as of the 1961 election, and twelve for the final general election to the Council in 1974. {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Yukon general election, 1900]] * [[Yukon general election, 1903]] * [[Yukon general election, 1905]] * [[Yukon general election, 1907]] * [[Yukon general election, 1909]] * [[Yukon general election, 1912]] * [[Yukon general election, 1915]] * [[Yukon general election, 1917]] * [[Yukon general election, 1920]] * [[Yukon general election, 1922]] * [[Yukon general election, 1925]] * [[Yukon general election, 1928]] * [[Yukon general election, 1931]] * [[Yukon general election, 1934]] * [[Yukon general election, 1937]] * [[Yukon general election, 1940]] * [[Yukon general election, 1944]] * [[Yukon general election, 1947]] * [[Yukon general election, 1949]] * [[Yukon general election, 1952]] * [[Yukon general election, 1955]] * [[Yukon general election, 1958]] * [[Yukon general election, 1961]] * [[Yukon general election, 1964]] * [[Yukon general election, 1967]] * [[Yukon general election, 1970]] * [[Yukon general election, 1974]] {{Div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{Cite web|url=http://www.electionalmanac.com/canada/yukon/results.php|title=Election Results|work=Election Almanac|accessdate=2009-07-01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710180039/http://www.electionalmanac.com/canada/yukon/results.php|archivedate=July 10, 2011|deadurl=yes}} (Results) * {{Cite web|url=http://www.electionsyukon.gov.yk.ca/gen-elections.html|title=General Elections|work=Elections Yukon|accessdate=2006-12-02}} (Dates; {{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} '''Marxist Communist Party of India''', MCPI was a [[political party]] in [[India]] that formed in 1983 under the leadership of comrade Mohan Punamia. It emerged as a splinter group of [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] stuck to the original 1964 programme. The party general secretary was [[Jagjit Singh Lyallpuri]] (former [[All India Kisan Sabha]] general secretary).
MCPI was active in [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[Bihar (India)|Bihar]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], [[West Bengal]], [[Rajasthan]], Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, etc.
The principal class mass organizations of the party were: * [[All India Centre of Trade Unions]] (AICTU) * [[All India Kisaan Federation]] (AIKF) * [[All India Agricultural Workers Federation]] (AIAWF) * [[All India Federation of Democratic Youth]] (AIFDY) * [[All India Federation of Democratic Women]] (AIFDW) * [[All India Federation of Democratic Students]] (AIFDS)
Ahead of the 2004 [[Lok Sabha]] elections MCPI participated in the front initiated by [[Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) Red Flag]] and [[Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) (Kanu Sanyal)|Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist)]].
In 2005 MCPI merged with other splinter groups to form the [[Marxist Communist Party of India (United)]].

{{other uses|Nabob (disambiguation)}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} [[File:Nabobs.jpg|thumb|alt=Four rows of caricatured profiles of men in 19th-century jackets and cravats, facing alternately right and left |An 1811 caricature of contemporary British nabobs]]
A '''nabob''' {{IPAc-en|'|n|eɪ|b|ɒ|b}} is a conspicuously wealthy man deriving his fortune in the [[Orient]], especially in [[India]] during the 18th century with the privately held [[East India Company]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Smylitopoulo, Christina| title=Portrait of a Nabob: Graphic Satire, Portraiture, and the Anglo-Indian in the Late Eighteenth Century| journal= Canadian Art Review| volume=37| issue=1|year= 2012 |url=http://www.racar-racar.com/uploads/5/7/7/4/57749791/2012_37_1_03_smylitopoulos.pdf}}</ref>
==Etymology==
''Nabob'' is an [[Anglo-Indian]] term that came to English from [[Urdu]], possibly from [[Hindustani language|Hindustani]] [[Nawab|''nawāb'']]/''navāb'',<ref name="OXF">{{cite web|url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/nabob|title=nabob|quote=from Portuguese nababo or Spanish nabab, from Urdu; see also nawab|publisher=oxforddictionaries.com |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> [[Loanword|borrowed]] into English during [[Colonial India|British colonial rule in India]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Slang dictionary, etymological, historical and anecdotal|year=1874| publisher=Chatto and Windus|place=London|page=233|url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924086360488#page/n250/mode/1up/}}</ref> It is possible this was via the intermediate [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ''nababo'', the Portuguese having preceded the British in [[India]].{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
The word entered colloquial usage in England from 1612. Native Europeans used ''nabob'' to refer to those who returned from India after having made a fortune there.<ref name="ETDIC">{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/etymology/nabobical|title=nabobical – Word Origin & History – nabob|quote=1612, "deputy governor in Mogul Empire," Anglo-Indian, from Hindi nabab, from Arabic nuwwab|publisher=dictionary.reference.com|accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref><ref name="MEM">{{cite web|url=http://www.memidex.com/nabob+governor|title=nabob (governor) |quote=Etymology:Hindi nawāb, nabāb, from Arabic nuwwāb, plural of nā'ib, deputy, active...|publisher=Memidex.com |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref>
The term was used by [[William Safire]] in a speech written for [[United States]] [[Vice President of the United States|Vice Pres]]. [[Spiro Agnew]] in 1970, which received heavy media coverage. Agnew, increasingly identified with his attacks on critics of the [[Nixon administration]], described these opponents as "nattering nabobs of negativism".<ref name="Nechtman">{{cite book |last=Nechtman |first=Tillman W. |title=Nabobs: Empire and Identity in Eighteenth-Century Britain |date=2010 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-52-176353-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AmY92eTAaloC}}</ref>{{rp|221}}<ref>{{cite news |author=Morrow, Lance |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,985217,00.html |title=Naysayer to the nattering nabobs |work=Time |date=30 September 1996 |accessdate=10 October 2011}}</ref>
In late 19th century [[San Francisco]], rapid urbanization led to an exclusive enclave of the rich and famous on the west coast who built large mansions in the [[Nob Hill, San Francisco|Nob Hill]] neighborhood. This included prominent tycoons such as [[Leland Stanford]], founder of [[Stanford University]] and other members of [[The Big Four (Central Pacific Railroad)|The Big Four]] who were known as ''nabobs'', which was shortened to nob, giving the area its eventual name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sftravel.com/article/nob-hill-touch-class|title=Nob Hill - A Touch of Class|publisher=|accessdate=13 October 2017}}</ref>
==History==
The English use of ''nabob'' was for a person who become rapidly wealthy in a foreign country, typically India, and returned home with considerable power and influence.<ref>{{cite book|author=J. Albert Rorabacher|title=Property, Land, Revenue, and Policy: The East India Company, C.1757–1825|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vCUlDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA236|year=2016|publisher=Taylor & Francis|page=236}}</ref> In England, the name was applied to men who made fortunes working for the [[East India Company]] and, on their return home, used the wealth [[rotten and pocket boroughs|to purchase seats]] in Parliament.<ref name="UKP">Related Information – Did you know?.</ref><ref name="BRIT">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/407089/nawab|title=nawab, English nabob|publisher=britannica.com |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref>
A common fear was that these individuals – the nabobs, their agents, and those who took their bribes – would use their wealth and influence to corrupt Parliament. The collapse of the Company's finances in 1772 due to bad administration, both in India and Britain, aroused public indignation towards the Company's activities and the behaviour of the Company's employees.<ref name="UKP"/> [[Samuel Foote]] gave a satirical look at those men who had enriched themselves through the East India Company in his 1772 play, ''[[The Nabob]]''.
This perception of the pernicious influence wielded by nabobs in both social and political life led to increased scrutiny of the East India Company. A number of prominent Company men underwent inquiries and impeachments on charges of corruption and misrule in India.<ref name="UKP"/> [[Warren Hastings]], first [[Governor-General of India]], was impeached in 1788 and acquitted in 1795 after a seven-year-long trial. [[Robert Clive, 1st Baron Clive]], [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Shrewsbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Shrewsbury]], was forced to defend himself against charges brought against him in the [[House of Commons of Great Britain|House of Commons]].<ref name="ETDIC"/>{{refn|name=Nechtman}}{{Page needed|date=May 2018}} [[Pitt's India Act]] of 1784 gave the British government effective control of the private company for the first time. The new policies were designed for an elite civil service career that minimized temptations for corruption.<ref>{{cite book|author=Tristram Hunt|title=Cities of Empire: The British Colonies and the Creation of the Urban World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6pVzAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA208|year=2014|publisher=Henry Holt |page=208}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Nobby]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/pathways/blackhistory/india/india_british.htm India and the British – The East India Company – Nabobs] * [http://www.fathom.com/course/21701766/session1.html The First Asians in Britain]

{{Infobox Museum |name = Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum |image = Nagasakigenbaku.jpg |imagesize = 280 |established = 1955,
built current museum 1996 |location = 7-8 Hirano-machi, [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]], [[Nagasaki Prefecture|Nagasaki]] |director = |website = [http://nagasakipeace.jp/index_e.html Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum] }} The {{nihongo|'''Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum'''|長崎原爆資料館|Nagasaki Genbaku Shiryōkan}} is in the city of [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]], [[Japan]]. The museum is a remembrance to the [[Bombing of Nagasaki|atomic bombing of Nagasaki]] by the United States of America 9 August 1945 at 11:02:35 am. Next to the museum is the [[Nagasaki National Peace Memorial Hall for the Atomic Bomb Victims]], built in 2003. The bombing marked a new era in war, making Nagasaki a symbolic location for a memorial.{{cite journal|last=Duffy|first=T. M.|title=The Making of a Peace Museum Tradition: Case-Studies from Japan and Cambodia|journal=Hiroshima Daigaku|year=1998}} The counterpart in [[Hiroshima]] is the [[Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum]]. These locations symbolize the nuclear age, remind visitors of the vast destruction and indiscriminate death caused by nuclear weapons, and signify a commitment to peace.{{cite journal|last=Duff|first=T|title=Civic zones of peace|year=1997|journal=Peace review|volume=9|series=2|pages=199–205}} The Nagasaki museum was completed in April 1996, replacing the deteriorating International Culture Hall.{{cite journal|last=Seltz|first=D|title=Remembering the War and the Atomic Bombs: New Museums, New Approaches|journal=Radical history review|year=1999|issue=75|pages=92–108}} The museum covers the history of the event as a story, focusing on the attack and the history leading up to it. It also covers the history of [[nuclear weapons]] development. The museum displays photographs, relics, and documents related to the bombing.{{cite web|url=http://www.at-nagasaki.jp/foreign/english/spot/003.html|title=Learn about the menace of the atomic bomb and the value of peace}} ==History of the Museum== The museum at the Nagasaki Peace Park replaced the Nagasaki International Culture Hall, where artifacts related to the bombing of Nagasaki were originally exhibited. These artifacts are now supplemented with photographs depicting daily life in Nagasaki before the atomic bomb was dropped, the devastation produced by the bomb, and the history of nuclear arms development.[http://www1.city.nagasaki.nagasaki.jp/peace/english/abm/download/leaflet_e.pdf], Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum English language leaflet. ==History covered in the museum== The Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum covers the history of the bombing of [[Nagasaki]], [[Japan]]. It portrays scenes of [[World War II]], the dropping of the atomic bomb, the reconstruction of Nagasaki, and present day. Additionally, the museum exhibits the history of [[nuclear weapons]] development.{{cite web|title=Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum|url=http://www.at-nagasaki.jp/foreign/english/spot/003.html|work=Nagasaki City Tourism Guide Amazing Nagasaki|accessdate=7 March 2013}} The atomic bomb was developed by scientists working under the [[Manhattan Project]]. The project was granted funding on December 6, 1941, with American leaders aiming for a new invention that would serve as a wartime weapon.{{cite web|last=Crane|first=Conrad|title=The Atomic Bomb (6 and 9 August 1945)|url=https://www.pbs.org/thewar/detail_5234.htm|publisher=PBS}} The decision to drop an atomic bomb on Japan had been made by 1943, and a shortlist of candidate target cities was in place in 1945. At the time, it was argued that an atomic bombing would bring about a more rapid end to the war. Hiroshima, the first target, was selected to show the power of America's new weapon. The second bombing, of Nagasaki, was intended to demonstrate that the [[United States of America|USA]] had a large arsenal.{{cite journal|last=Zuberi|first=Martin|title=Atomic Bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|journal=Strategic Analysis|year=2001|volume=25|series=5|pages=623–662|doi=10.1080/09700160108458986}} At 11:02 A.M. local time on August 9, 1945, the atomic bomb, nicknamed [[Fat Man]] as its code name by [[Robert Serber]] [[Fat Man#Naming|in the United States]] (after [[Sydney Greenstreet]]'s character in ''[[The Maltese Falcon (1941 film)|The Maltese Falcon]]''){{cite book |last=Jones |first=Vincent |title=Manhattan: The Army and the Atomic Bomb |publisher=United States Army Center of Military History |location=Washington, DC |year=1985 |url=http://www.history.army.mil/html/books/011/11-10/CMH_Pub_11-10.pdf |page=517 |accessdate=25 August 2013|oclc=10913875 |ref=harv }} was dropped on Nagasaki, forever changing the city's landscape. A mushroom cloud rose to an altitude of 45,000 feet above the city. Within the museum is a history of the city before the bomb was dropped. The [[hypocenter]] of the explosion was the Urakami district, which was a traditionally rustic and isolated suburb. However, the population soared after the 1920s when the district was chosen as the site for munitions factories. An industrial zone was quickly created. Additionally, the Urakami district was home to the Nagasaki Medical College. When the bomb was dropped at 11:02 A.M. on August 9, 1945, the 20 neighborhoods within a one-kilometer radius of the hypocenter were completely destroyed by the heat flash and blast winds generated by the explosion. They were then reduced to ashes by the fires which followed. Within 2 km of the hypocenter, roughly 80% of the houses collapsed and burned. When the smoke cleared, the area was strewn with corpses.{{cite web|title=1945.8.9 At 11:02 a.m. August 9, 1945|url=http://www1.city.nagasaki.nagasaki.jp/peace/english/record/photo/part_2_01.html|work=Nagasaki City-Peace & Atomic Bomb|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523122932/http://www1.city.nagasaki.nagasaki.jp/peace/english/record/photo/part_2_01.html|archivedate=May 23, 2013|df=}} Reconstruction of the city proceeded slowly. It was not until the latter half of 1946 that the first emergency dwellings were provided to the communities. The need for buildings far surpassed the availabilities. As late as 1950, applications for corporate dwellings exceeded the availability ninety times.{{cite web|title=After the Bomb: Life in the Ruins|url=http://atomicbombmuseum.org/4_ruins.shtml|author=AtomicBombMuseum.org}} The national government of Japan created a war disaster reconstruction plan in November 1945 which projected a city concept which would abandon the old war industries and focus instead on a revival of foreign trade, shipbuilding, and the fishing industry. Today, the city is considered a peace city and has pledged itself to the mission of world peace.{{cite journal|last=Duffy|first=Terence|title=The Peace Museums of Japan|journal=Museum International|date=28 June 2008|volume=49|issue=4|pages=49–54|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0033.1997.tb00012.x}} ==Inside the Museum== The residents of Nagasaki consider it their duty to make sure the horrors which they experienced due to the atomic bombing are never repeated.{{cite web|title=Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum|url=http://www1.city.nagasaki.nagasaki.jp/peace/english/abm/|publisher=Nagasaki Aatomic Bomb Museum|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64zoZgZS7?url=http://www1.city.nagasaki.nagasaki.jp/peace/english/abm/|archivedate=2012-01-27|df=}} Because of this, the museum is designed in such a way that the audience can see just what effect the bomb had on the city, the reconstruction, and the lasting effects of the atomic bomb. The museum opens with a room dedicated to the city as it was just before the bomb decimated Nagasaki. A clock which stopped at 11:02, the precise time the bomb hit the city, is also on display to demonstrate how so many people were killed in an instant. In the next section, visitors enter a room which shows Nagasaki just after the bombings. Included in this room is a water tank with contorted legs which was located at Keiho Middle School, approximately 800m away from the hypocenter of the bombing. The section "Events leading up to the Nagasaki Atomic Bombiing" isolates historical events from contemporary biases. The permanent exhibition rooms display large materials exposed to the blast, as well as a replica of a sidewall of the [[Urakami Cathedral]] which was hit by the bomb. The purpose is to reproduce the state which the city was in immediately after the bombing. Photographs and facts are shown alongside artifacts left by the deceased.{{cite web|title=Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum Brochure|url=http://www1.city.nagasaki.nagasaki.jp/peace/english/abm/download/leaflet_e.pdf|work=Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum}} Additionally, the second section contains some of the rosaries found inside the Urakami Cathedral. At the time of the bombing, dozens of people were inside the Cathedral for confession. This section also exhibits a timeline of events which shows a course of events that occurred prior to the bomb being dropped in Nagasaki. Leaflets which American forces dropped on Japan during the early part of 1945 are on display. One gives information on the bombing of Hiroshima and the power of the atomic bomb, warning citizens to leave the city and stop fighting. Also included are melted bottles, the bones of a human hand stuck to a clump of melted glass, burnt clothing, a lunchbox with its contents still charred inside of it, and a helmet with the remains of a victim’s skull on the inner surface. Section B shows damage caused by the [[radiation]], damages caused by the blast, appeals of the [[atomic bomb survivors]], and the rescue and relief activities which were carried out. After viewing the city scene, museum visitors are invited to think about issues related to war and [[nuclear non-proliferation]]. This section of the museum contains the political sections entitled "The Road to the Atomic Bombing" and "The War between China and Japan and the Pacific War". It is there that the experience of militarism in Japan and the demands of war are juxtaposed with arguments for the end of [[nuclear weapons]]. Visitors are presented with facts on modern [[nuclear weapons]] alongside facts related to victims of the atomic bombing. It is a call for peace and an end of the nuclear age. The final room in the museum contains videos and documents related to the [[Nagasaki bombing]]. Visitors can also find answers to their questions and documents like Nagasaki’s Peace Declaration. ==Maintenance of Exhibits== The museum exhibits objects that were exposed to radiation from the atomic bomb. Though some materials are double-cased, display techniques generally are not tailored in any special way for the preservation of these materials.[http://scholar.googleusercontent.com/scholar?q=cache:6vDPJkWZRPAJ:scholar.google.com/+%22nagasaki+atomic+bomb+museum%22&hl=en&as_sdt=0,9 page 22.] ==Criticism== When the museum initially opened in 1966 there was criticism of the re-interpretation of Japanese history. Furthermore, the museum was considered highly political, as it presented only one side of the story and did not promote the concept of peace. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{commonscatinline}} * [http://www.at-nagasaki.jp/foreign/english/spot/003.html Nagasaki City Tourist Guide information] * [http://nagasakipeace.jp/english.html The Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Museum] * [http://e.nagasaki.mapping.jp/ Nagasaki Archive] Nagasaki atomic bombing archive on Google Earth {{coord|32|46|22|N|129|51|54|E|type:landmark_region:JP-42|display=title}} [[Category:Aftermath of war]] [[Category:Peace museums]] [[Category:Monuments associated with the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] [[Category:Museums in Nagasaki]] [[Category:World War II museums in Japan]] [[Category:Museums established in 1955]] [[Category:City museums in Japan]] [[Category:Peace]] [[Category:1955 establishments in Japan]]

[[File:President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles in 1956.jpg|thumb|250px|Secretary of State [[John Foster Dulles]], right, shown here with President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Eisenhower]] in 1956, became identified with the doctrine of "massive retaliation."]] The '''New Look''' was the name given to the [[national security]] policy of the [[United States of America|United States]] during the administration of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]. It reflected Eisenhower's concern for balancing the [[Cold War]] military commitments of the United States with the nation's financial resources. The policy emphasized reliance on [[Military strategy#Cold War strategy|strategic]] [[nuclear weapon]]s to [[deterrence theory|deter]] potential threats, both [[conventional weapon|conventional]] and nuclear, from the [[Eastern Bloc]] of nations headed by the [[Soviet Union]]. ==History== [[Image:Eisenhower inspects YB52.jpg|thumb|250px|President Eisenhower and members of his Cabinet inspect the YB-52 prototype of the [[B-52 Stratofortress|B-52]].]] In its narrowest sense, the New Look was the name applied to the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] budget for [[Fiscal year|Fiscal Year]] 1955, which was the first defense budget prepared entirely by Eisenhower's own [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]]. It was based on an extensive reappraisal of U.S. military requirements that began among Eisenhower and his closest advisers immediately following his election in November 1952.Herman S. Wolk, [http://www.airforcemag.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2003/August%202003/0803look.aspx "The 'New Look',"] ''Air Force Magazine'', v. 65, no. 8, (August 2003). {{ISSN|0730-6784}} It was formalized in [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] document [[NSC 162/2|162/2]] (NSC 162/2), which Eisenhower approved on October 30, 1953. NSC 162/2 reflected Eisenhower's desire for a "long-haul" approach to security planning that would maintain a more or less constant level of military preparedness, consistent with the health of the [[U.S. economy]].Samuel P. Huntington, ''The Common Defense'', New York: Columbia University Press, 1961, pp. 67–68. {{ISBN|0-231-08566-4}} In this respect, it differed from [[NSC 68]], approved by President Harry S. Truman on September 30, 1950. Truman's advisers believed that Soviet military capabilities would reach a maximum relative to those of the United States and its allies in the mid-1950s.Quoted in Huntington, p. 66. Eisenhower rejected the idea that one period would be any more dangerous than another and urged his planners to think in terms of a Soviet threat that was economic as well as military. He wanted to avoid, in his own words, "an unbearable security burden leading to economic disaster." With the costly experience of the [[Korean War]] in mind, Eisenhower was fearful that U.S. resources would be drained by Soviet-inspired regional conflicts. ==Massive Retaliation and the New Look== [[File:WB-47E.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[B-47 Stratojet|B-47]] long-range bomber was the mainstay of U.S. deterrence during most of the New Look.]] [[File:B-52A.jpg|thumb|250px|A [[B-52 Stratofortress|B-52]] long-range bomber. The first models were deployed just as the New Look took shape.]] In order to contain defense costs, the New Look brought about a shift in emphasis from conventional military capability to "air-atomic" capability in the form of the [[Strategic Air Command]] within a scaled-down overall military establishment. Land and naval forces were cut. Continental air defense was expanded. Although strategic air power attained a lower level than the Truman administration had projected, it became the centerpiece of U.S. security thinking, embodied in the doctrine of "[[Massive retaliation|Massive Retaliation]]." Summarized in the popular slogan "more bang for the buck," Massive Retaliation was intended to be both a deterrent to an enemy and an [[economy of scale]] if deterrence failed.Huntington, pp. 79–80. The doctrine was proclaimed in its most absolute form by [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[John Foster Dulles]] in a speech before the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] on January 12, 1954, in which he said, "Local defenses must be reinforced by the further deterrent of ''massive retaliatory power'' [emphasis added].Quoted in Bernard Brodie, ''Strategy in the Missile Age'', (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1959, p. 248. Dulles continued:
''The way to deter aggression is for the free community to be willing and able to respond vigorously at places and with means of its own choosing. ... ''Now the Department of Defense and the Joint Chiefs of Staff can shape our military establishment to fit what is our policy, instead of having to try to be ready to meet the enemy's many choices. That permits of a selection of military means instead of a multiplication of means, As a result, it is now possible to get, and share, more basic security at less cost.''''Id.'', pp. 248–249. McGeorge Bundy, a national security adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, states that President Eisenhower, although initially put off by the phrase "massive retaliatory power," not only approved the Dulles speech, but had a hand in drafting it. McGeorge Bundy, ''Danger and Survival'', New York: Random House, 1988, p. 256. {{ISBN|0-394-52278-8}}
===Criticism of Massive Retaliation=== What Dulles implied was that the United States was prepared to respond to a Soviet-backed conventional threat anywhere with a nuclear strike against the Soviet Union itself.This was not a new theme for Dulles. In a 1952 article for ''Life'' magazine, he wrote: "There is one solution and only one: that is for the free world to develop the will and organize the means to retaliate instantly against open aggression by Red armies, so that, if it occurred anywhere, we could and would strike back where it hurts, by means of our choosing." John Foster Dulles, '"A Policy of Boldness," ''Life'', May 19, 1952, p. 151. Quoted in Townsend Hoopes, ''The Devil and John Foster Dulles'', (Boston: Little, Brown & Co., 1973), p. 127. {{ISBN|0-316-37235-8}} Dulles, however, was not alone in suggesting a nuclear response to a conventional threat. On January 11, 1951, at the height of the Korean War, former [[United States Secretary of the Air Force|Secretary of the Air Force]] [[Stuart Symington]], then chair of the [[National Security Resources Board]], sent President Truman the draft of [http://www.mtholyoke.edu/acad/intrel/korea/nsc100.htm NSC 100], which proposed using nuclear weapons not only against [[People's Republic of China|China]], which was engaged in active combat with U.S. forces, but also against the Soviet Union, which was believed to be conducting the war through China. Truman rejected the memorandum. James Carroll, ''House of War'', Boston & New York: Houghton Mifflin Co., 2006, pp. 193, 202. {{ISBN|0-618-18780-4}} Critics of Massive Retaliation such as historian [[John Lewis Gaddis]] have pointed out that the doctrine was not credible in the face of "less-than-total challenges" such as the Soviet intervention in the [[1956 Hungarian Revolution]], and that whatever credibility it might have had diminished steadily as Soviet strategic power grew.John Lewis Gaddis, ''Strategies of Containment: A Critical Appraisal of Postwar American National Security'' New York: Oxford University Press, 1982. {{ISBN|0-19-517448-8}} Furthermore, it theoretically provided the Soviet Union with an incentive to strike first to disarm the United States. The Hungarian Revolution involved a matter internal to the Eastern Bloc, so it is unclear whether any sort of conventional military response would have been undertaken regardless. {{anchor|The "New" New Look}} =="New" New Look== [[File:1958-02-06 Atomic Weapons come to Korea.ogv|thumb|1958 deployment of tactical atomic weapons in Korea.]] The refusal of the United States to act to prevent the defeat of [[France]] by the [[Communist Party of Vietnam|Communist]]-led [[Viet Minh]] at the [[Battle of Dien Bien Phu]], just four months after the Dulles speech, was proof that a situation of "mutual deterrence" had developed with the Soviet Union in which the use of strategic nuclear weapons for any purpose other than to respond to a direct attack on one's homeland or on one's major allies was out of the question. Defense planners, therefore, began shaping a "new" New Look marked by emphasis on strategic "sufficiency," not superiority; on [[tactical nuclear weapon]]s to fight "limited wars;" and on standing forces as opposed to reserves.See generally, Huntington, pp. 88–100. Huntington uses the term "New New Look." So does George E. Lowe, ''The Age of Deterrence'', Boston: Little, Brown & Co., 1964, p. 89. Apparently without access to the then-classified NSC 5440, Huntington placed the beginning of the "New New Look" in December 1955 when Department of Defense planners began budget preparations for fiscal years 1958, 1959 and 1960. The emphasis was still primarily on nuclear weapons and the justification was still that of economy, but a shift toward what would later be called "[[flexible response]]" had begun. The new approach was embodied in NSC{{nbsp}}5440 (approved as NSC{{nbsp}}5501 on January 7, 1955),{{cite book|last=Mitrovich|first=Gregory|title=Undermining the Kremlin: America's Strategy to Subvert the Soviet Bloc, 1947-1956|date=2000|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=0801437113|page=[https://books.google.no/books?id=w6TVdT-q7vcC&pg=PA166 166]|language=en}} finalized in December 1954, which stated:
''The ability to apply force selectively and flexibly will become increasingly important in maintaining the morale and will of the free world to resist aggression. As the fear of nuclear war grows, the United States and its allies must never allow themselves to get into the position where they must choose between (a) not responding to local aggression and (b) applying force in a way which our own people or our allies would consider entails undue risk of nuclear devastation. However, the United States cannot afford to preclude itself from using nuclear weapons even in a local situation, if such use. . . will best advance U.S. security interests. In the last analysis, if confronted by the choice of (a) acquiescing in Communist aggression or (b) taking measures risking either general war or loss of allied support, the United States must be prepared to take these risks if necessary for its security.''Quoted in Campbell Craig, ''Destroying the Village: Eisenhower and Thermonuclear War'' New York: Columbia University Press, 1998, chapter 3. {{ISBN|0-231-11123-1}}
According to historian [[Campbell Craig]]:
''NSC 5440 was a fundamental revision of the earlier BNSP'' [Basic National Security Policy]. ''Its authors (a) renounced massive retaliation, (b) precisely articulated the strategy of "flexible response" as it would become known seven years later, and (c) predicted, in the last sentence, exactly the dilemma which the Eisenhower administration would face in Berlin four years hence.''
